content.body: Okay, hg's response to a config file format error seems to be a backtrace.
Seriously.
How can this possibly be considered acceptable in real software?
Wow, people had \
Wow, people had fun filing bugs the day before the deadline.
Especially Microsoft.
AryehGregor, bugs for what?
http://w3.org/Bugs/Public
Spec bugs.
ah
What's with the data property of an ImageData Object returned from createImageData or getImageData being read-only?
All the browsers except IE9 allow you to write (and should for raw display-out capabilities).
This is blocking my js gameboy color from using the canvas object for display out.
It has to fall back to drawing via BMP images created by data uris
site: http://grantgalitz.org/gameboy/
The each value inside the CanvasPixelArray object should be able to be written to
But IE9 is the browser that disagrees. WTF?
that's just a bug in IE9 then
data is marked readonly because you cannot write to data, but you can write to the object it returns
Yeah, you shouldn't be able to alter the array count / add / delete the indices, and they should have to fall between 0 and 255
write with restrictions. ;)
annek: ok
Then the IE9 team read that wrong. :P
there's a whole lot of things that work that way
so that'd be scary
Since there's "limited writing" to the indices.
but maybe they don't do it consistently wrong
IE9 throws a read-only error on setting an indice.
Even though the value to write is valid and so is the indice.
wird
*weird
Unless my emu has a hidden bug that's only triggering a fault in IE9. :P
The emu actually works btw.
At least most roms do.
Some bugs still. :(
The JS N64 emu is even worse.
Which is why it isn't live yet.
It has tons of issues with WebG.> :(
*WebGL
N64? that'd be great
annevk: ARM emulation for the GBA is coming up shortly (before the N64 emu).
At least ARM has documentation. :P
*more than the GBC :P
yeah
Almost all the N64 game roms crash
some exceptions though
Mario Kart & Diddy kong racing
Though WebGL matrices are way off on them.
And a buggy Firefox 4 beta 7 pre isn't making life any easier.
Though the documentation on the reality chip for the n64 is sometimes hard to come by, just like the gameboy's cpu docs.
Damn Nintendo changing the Zilog Z80 CPU around.
almost has kirby 64 running on the js n64 emu at least.
Though I need to work on the GBC emu some more
Pokemon Crystal badly fucks up after the intro
And the clock cycle timing isn't right yet.
Though Pokemon Yellow seems to run perfectly. :P
color and all
except sound
Sound is fucked up on my part.
Still not ready on sound.
annevk: Works in IE8 at 1fps. ;)
(IE 8, not 9)
IE9 works at 5 fps
annevk: When is chrome going to fix the memory leak with assigning long arrays onto a canvas context?
Just seems like a bad security issue
As well as data uri'd images.
google chrome leaks a lot of shit and runs systems of of memory accidentally when running my emu
Firefox, opera, ie don't have this prob
grantg, better ask someone from Google :)
heh
Lots of rendering glitches in Opera & chrome
Opera wins overall
but euh, keep up the good work; I love playing games in the browser
Try to visit my emu in Opera and you'll be horrified.
oh, if you find bugs in Opera please file them at bugs.opera.com/wizard
I have
cool
The opera dev team has ignored them for 6 months at least
oh, let me poke them for you
can you /msg me your email or the bug IDs?
Box-shadow is *trashed* c o m p l e t e l y. Did I say completely trashed. YES.
annevk: grantgalitzâŠ™gc
Should be in the db
should definitely make sure games work in our browser
great
And SVG rendering is fucked up when used in css backgrounds in Opera whena doc is scrolling
Not to mention the opacity bug where the browser's rendering engine incorrectly stacks the virtual buffers wrong.
So UI elements like scrollbars and buttons appear behind the opacity-given element when in the element.
Opera gets its logic right, but not the rendering logic right.
annevk: Do they have my bugs, they should be there.
If you need me to re-fill out the reports, ok.
Opera's rendering is buggy on all OSes. :(
there's some weird way we store bugs from external reporters and I forgot how to search that
hmm
Should I double report?
if you have the bug IDs that'd make it easier for me
Not the IDs.
I haven't been to their site in awhile, nor have I copied down any #s.
needs to go soon.
I found one bug
Heh, found a GBC rom that shows off Mode 7. lol @ crude 3D on the gameboy.
annevk: It might be listed under other emails too.
Like one of my half-dozen AOL accounts.
yes, AOL. :(
heh, do they have something in common?
would definitely be easier if you used just one address
I should just re-report the damn bugs.
that works too
It's easy to see them
At least half-dozen on the gameboy emu
Browse http://grantgalitz.org/gameboy/ and you'll eventually find some bugs.
These 'windows' are movable and resizable.
Moving them glitches out opera.
Clearly Opera bugs when you move them.
yeah
bah
lol
Trashed, right?
Do you need a rom
Remember, you can load any rom from any address
or you can load them in locally
I was wondering about samples
no presets?
Either through the File API or through Base64 copy+paste
You mean providing roms for you?
yeah, though I guess you'd violate some copyright then
I'd call that illegal or borderline illegal
like jsnes
I can give you any unlicensed rom though
http://grantgalitz.org/gameboy/romStorage/proxima.gb
copy+paste that address into the emu
or dl the rom and load it in from your comp
you need some kind of controls page
x is a
z is b
shift is select
enter/return is start
annevk: yeah
and the arrow keys are the arrow keys.
annevk: You can play most games even right before GBA came out
2001 GBC games work as good as 1998 GBC games
Like mario tennis
and Super Mario Bros Deluxe
and Pokemon Yellow / Red / Blue
And Microsof pinball
etc
*MicroSoft
and more...
box-shadow issue is already resolved btw
When?
will hopefully be in public builds soon
Thank god
It's been there since the 10.50 alphas
annevk: Notice when resizing the 'window' vertically very slowly the inside div doesn't resize as well?
Bug in opera. :P
very very weird position: absolute bug.
with inline-block
some weird logic
Like a check in opera is getting missed.
annevk: BTW, the site renders as application/xhtml+xml for browsers that send that mime type in the accept header.
So it will present itself as true XHTML to the browsers that support it.
:D
Hixie, http://www.emendapp.com/sites/www.whatwg.org
None of that broken fake-o-xhtml shit that 99% of the web does.
so that you can use inline SVG?
Correction, 99+%
annevk: I don't use inline svg
Just as CSS backgrounds
As fallback when CSS3 gradients aren't supported
so that ie6-8 users will still be happy when your site is broken but ie9 users and users of other browsers will be unhappy?
IE8 gets MicroSoft's proprietary gradient filter
IE 6 & 7 cannot work with the emu
they suck and will not run it
brb
hg pull is crashing on me?
is this because I pushed to a different repository before or something?
gah
annevk: No, you should be able to push and pull from different repos
What error are you getting?
I think it's due to VPN
I disabled VPN and now things work
can I pull and push to two repositories by default btw?
so that I don't have to keep them in sync manually?
also
*summons* Ms2ger
I don't think you can make hg pull and hg push always work with two different repositories
at the same time
too bad
wonders if Leif actually uses System 9
what's System 9?
The Mac operating system from before OSX
ah
loads a compiled rom of unix made for gameboy z80 derived cpus and loads it into the js emu.
bliss
unix in js
loads http://grantgalitz.org/gameboy/romStorage/Unix%20(PD).gb into http://grantgalitz.org/gameboy/
managed to "aw, Snap!" Google Chrome once more with the emu (WebKit is unstable and leaks a lot in the File API)
*unstable in the file api
annevk: When is the bug fix release coming out approx?
This month or next?'
Or "when we feel like it"?
Hopefully soon is the best I can do
Yeah, this is the kind of bug where box-shadow should be disabled by default until it's fixed.
breaks whenever the effect is altered (on /off) or moved around.
I'm going to sleep
nn
jgraham: does http://www.w3.org/html/wg/wiki/ChangeProposals/FigureInP#Details look sane to you?
hsivonen: table-row seems like an annoying style since it can't have a border in the separated table border model (which is the default)
hsivonen: you could say figure { border-collapse:collapse } in the ua style sheet but then that would affect descendant tables
zcorpan: would table-cell make more sense?
zcorpan: hmm. actually, it would not
hsivonen: Why do you want it to be scoping?
zcorpan: what would you suggest for the default UA style sheet for figure and figcaption
hsivonen: display:block for both
zcorpan: OK
jgraham: to make <pre> as the figured element work
(and <table>)
we'd want the caption text to wrap to the width of the image, which display:table doesn't do
if we try hard enough to get it right, what we have accomplished is a headache for authors who will need more rules in their reset.css to make a default they can understand
zcorpan: ok
zcorpan: I removed the UA style sheet changes
jgraham: it's covered in the "Rationale" section :-)

allowing 
 and  nested in 
 through
annevk: why?
because that is the kind of authoring insanity I was hoping we would go away from

does not work in

, but you can hack around that with
annevk: authors want to put tables inside paragraphs already. Why should we get in the way
because if this is the only way they can do that everyone will just end up getting confused
annevk: table not working in p is a flaw on the format. I would not hold hacking around flaws of the format against authors
s/on/of/
we should have fixed the flaw when that was still possible
adding special cases around the flaw instead of just accepting it as an inherent limitation seems misguided
annevk: you know how hard it is to fix a flaw like that. http://ln.hixie.ch/?start=1137799947&count=1
annevk: if we don't fix figure now, we'll get one of those blog posts 7 years from now
not at all
actually, it's worse than 7 years. Mozilla still hasn't shipped a release with Web-compatible comment parsing
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/last-html-quirk/ is the flaw
and we know we cannot fix it
annevk: what could I do to the Change Proposal draft to make you not object to it if it went to a poll?
I think the content model would have to remain transparent
annevk: my point is that
annevk: that's an edit I'm not willing to make at this point :-(
I'm fine with
annevk: transparent content models are weird rules for normal people (where normal people means people who don't hang out here)
Having certain elements be allowed as descendants sometimes and not work at all when you remove an element inbetween is just too magical
annevk: I claim that people think more in terms of parent-child than in terms of ancestor-descendant when it comes to content models
I think transparent content models are always weird

I think people would find it very weird if they can suddenly nest inside

through
I think having
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10692#c9 -- I wonder how often I will have to keep explaining this to people
annevk: the suggestion in that bug is about the coersion rules, and browsers don't implement the coersion rules, so the html[xmlns] thing is a non-issue
that's just what the title says
he's actually asking for something else

e.g. "I don't necessarily care how this is done as long as the Javascript that is executed on the document, intended to find "xmlns:*" mappings, doesn't have to have two code paths depending on if the document is in HTML5-mode or XHTML5-mode."
might be worthwhile to point out in the bug then that changing the coersion rules does not affect javascript/dom in the browser
feel free
Isn't Manu asking for the attribute to be put in the DOM in *both* the XMLNS NS and in no namespace?
It sounds pretty insane, but like it would not break with a simple html[xmlns] selector
oh
that would be insane
Well yeah, but you need a different example it would break, or some other argument that the insanity isn't worth the perceived value
(to me it is obvious that adding that kind of complexity to support the usecase "people want to use features that were designed to not work in HTML" isn't a good idea)
Especially given the number of people involved, and there are alterntaives that are designed to work in HTML
thanks for pointing that out
Do reftests in Gecko work by getting a hash of the entire viewport, or does it depend upon window size?
gsnedders: AFAIK reftest uses canvas
it paints two pages to canvas and compares them
How big is the canvas?
jgraham: seems like it takes the canvas size from the element which contains the web page
so the size of iframe or so
(I'm just reading the code...)
smaug____: okay
The browser element (== iframe) has style="min-width: 800px; min-height: 1000px; max-width: 800px; max-height: 1000px"
gsnedders: ^
Aren't there tests that don't work in an iframe?
I'm thinking of viewport0related CSS stuff
jgraham: well, it is actually <xul:browser type="content-primary"> so the contents of it is the top level content page
Ah
wonders if all the FOs raised in the first months of the HTML WG's existence have become moot and no longer tracked: http://dev.w3.org/html5/status/formal-objection-status.html
hsivonen: i thought that all FOs would be tracked and presented to the Director when the time comes, but i don't know how it works exactly
zcorpan: that's what I thought, too
hsivonen: i think Hixie meant css whitespace as in whitespace the actual style sheet, not what the white-space property thinks is white space in the document
Oh more bugspam
zcorpan: oh. ok.
zcorpan: this stuff is confusing!

maybe it's possible to change css's definition of whitespace to exclude the form feed too, but i don't think the csswg are willing to do that (they didn't want to add u+000b as whitespace to match html5 back when html5 had that, which was in part why u+000b was removed from html5)
(the other reason was that u+000b wasn't consistently implemented as whitespace in browsers anyway)
zcorpan: consistently implemented on the parser layer, yes. Not consistently implemented throughout the engine.
hsivonen: iirc there was something with ie not always considering u+000b to be whitespace in the parser, but i forget the details
is this pre-LC component barred from accepting new bugs?
it would have been nice to disable bugmail during the mass update
hsivonen: true
does that now
problem is that when I do disable it, I usually forget to turn it back on
anyone know where I could find: "Robin Berjon"? (re: <device>)
f1lt3r: Blog? Twitter? Email?
Street address?
hi guys
may I ask how exactly the whole versioning mechanism came to be in WebSQL?
because as far as I can see it's 1) completely broken 2) totally unsuitable for the single stating purpose, ie. ensuring that a known and supported schema version is being used
gsnedders: As long as your initial guess is "sufficiently close", yeah, it'll terminate.
http://pastebin.com/MUJTBXza
my understanding of these snippets is that you can never successfully change the schema version unless you happen to guess the existing version exactly
you can also never *read* the version, making it basically impossible to check if you know how to operate on the data safely
Amusing: http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=57816
also, http://www.w3.org/TR/webdatabase talks about read/write mode a lot, but no method takes a parameter called "mode"
in particular, transaction() / readTransaction() don't, and it's implied they should
http://www.w3.org/TR/webdatabase/#dom-database-transaction
TabAtkins: Yeah, that's what I found looking online. So I concluded my working had gone wrong. :)
(I later found my mistake, and just made it to his English Language lecture on time)
s/his/my/
blatantly uses actions way too much
Hixie: http://barkavenueblog.blogspot.com/2009/04/tokyo-cat-cafe-big-business.html (via wilhelm)
hi fans
I came to ask about the PUT/DELETE removal from http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#attr-fs-method
any word on that?

are any of the people who commented on the link relation thread planning to write up a proposal of the wiki-based approach? (AryehGregor? hober? TabAtkins?) I haven't seen a volunteer yet and if no one does it then the IANA approach will win by default, which would be unfortunate given the number of people advocating the microformats wiki instead
othermaciej: What's the deadline?
October 27
Yeah, I'll do it if no one else picks it up.
I'll help with it, but I don't want to drive. :)
tantek would be a good person to have help on that
Yeah, that's what I was thinking too.
okay, guys, WTF
why does executeSql work async?
is the fact the transaction callback is run asynchronously already not enough?
I'm surprised that ResultSets can be accessed without involving callbacks somewhere
mathrick: anything that might take more than zero time is async, otherwise the browser might lock up while the call is happening
Hixie: then to be honest rows.length should also be async, as as the spec notes it might be expensive
hi Hixie
besides, there are already *Sync() variants, so the lockup is still possible
Hixie, did you get back to anyone on that missing PUT/DELETE thing?
Hixie: and unrelated to async, I still think that the whole changeVersion() interface is horribly broken
why does it not pass in the current DB version?
you have no way to enumerate DBs, and no way to learn the current version
so you have to try each possible combination of versions until one works
mathrick: yeah, the .rows being sync and the changeVersion() API sucking are known bugs. That spec is dead though so I doubt anything will happen to fix those problems.
*sigh*

Hixie: so we have WebSQL, which is a huge pain to use, and broken in many places, and will never be supported by Mozilla, and IndexedDB, which is similarly broken but doesn't give a useful query language
For the broken parts, comment on it!
proposed specs should not have glaring bugs apparent on the first reading ever :(
it = IndexedDB.
TabAtkins: the draft at W3C doesn't have a nice comment box like the whatwg documents do
but in a nutshell, it's race conditions waiting to happen
No, but it has a mailing list.
"Every method for making asynchronous requests returns an IDBRequest object that communicates back to the requesting application through events." <-- here be race conditions

mathrick: yes. Not much I can do about either though. If you want Web SQL DB resurrected, convince Mozilla and Microsoft to implement it (I'll spec the SQL profile if necessary). If you want IndexedDB to not suck, send comments on it, it's a work in progress.
http://www.w3.org/TR/IndexedDB/#idl-def-IDBRequest <-- No method for providing error handlers upon creation, and no method to read if it's finished with an error or not
IRC is not a good place to send feedback
mathrick: I'm not an editor of that spec, nor is Hixie.  Email the list.
it's especially not a good place for IndexedDB since none of the IndexedDB editors are here :-)
yeah, I'm just being disheartened by the piles of brokenness I encounter every time I try to use the newer APIs
http://reprog.wordpress.com/2010/09/05/bibliographic-data-part-3-has-anyone-anywhere-ever-read-the-whole-of-the-rda-specification/ Never let anyone tell you that HTML5 is too long, ever again
oh my.
"As best I can tell, the current total is about 1640 pages â€” so if you printed it out on standard 80 gsm paper, it would be 17 cm thick (nearly 7 inches) and weigh something over 8 kg (18 pounds)."
it is still less than the changelog of Irak article on wikipedia ;) http://booktwo.org/notebook/wikipedia-historiography/
Is there really no way to tell Bugzilla not to notify everyone when you make mass changes like renaming a component?
Well it is a bit unfair to compare full history against a single snapshot
complete.html is about 500-600 pages, but that doesn't include things like SVG, CSS, MathML, HTTP, etc, which really should be part of the same spec IMHO, if we're going to spec The Platform
what are the 1640 pages speccing?
the blog post wasn't clear about that
http://www.rdatoolkit.org/home
http://www.rdatoolkit.org/constituencyreview
from what I can see it is also using a large font. This kind of stats would be better counting words more than pages. Still it is a lot
they use extensive prose to describe each feature
example: 2.3.1.1
A title is a word, phrase, character, or group of characters that
names a resource or a work contained in it.

More than one title may appear in the resource itself (e.g., on a title page, title frame, etc.; as a caption title, running title, etc.; on a cover, spine, etc.; on a title bar, etc.), on a jacket, sleeve, container, etc., or in material accompanying the resource.
they have also a *lot* of examples
Philip`: yt?
